p: The frequency of resistance in seasonal A/H1N1 viruses increased from 2005 to 2007, primarily due to the Ser31Asn mutation [ 29, 30]. Fortunately, the incidence of primary resistance declined in 2008 and 2009 among seasonal A/H1N1 viruses as oseltamivir-resistant viruses predominated [ 44]. This seasonal A/H1N1 virus, which was replaced by the 2009 pandemic A/H1N1 virus, was primarily resistant to the M2 inhibitors generally due to the Ser31Asn mutation [ 44]. As a result, all currently circulating strains of influenza A are primarily resistant to the M2 inhibitors, and this class of drug is not recommended for the prevention or treatment of influenza [ 2].
